docs.title: Welcome
docs.text: Selena Wang, PhD selena.wang@yale.edu Department of Biostatistics Yale University New Haven, CT, 06520 I am an incoming assistant professor of Biostatistics and Health Data Science at Indiana Univeristy School of Medicine. I have published in both methodology and application journals including Psychometrika, Biostatistics, Journal of Complex Networks and Behavior Research Methods. My methodology research focus on high-dimensional networks, multivariate analysis and latent variable models with specializations in neuroimaging data and social and political networks. Researchers interested in collaborative works should email me at selena.wang@yale.edu

docs.title: Additional Information
docs.text: You can find me on GoogleScholar and ResearchGate.

docs.title: Research
docs.text: Network science is interdisciplinary. Focusing on improving current analytical strategies, I try to absorb influences of other disciplines to inform and improve understandings about human behaviors with applications in neuroscience, psychiatry, psychology and others. Broadly speaking, I model real-world networks with statistically sound principles and methods—reduce network complexity, perform intuitive visualization and test critical hypotheses with improved statistical power and controlled type I errors. I am particularly interested in the topological structures of networks and the roles they play in (neuro)degeneration, (neuro)development and resilience.

docs.title: Brain Networks
docs.text:
Tian, X., Wang, Y., Wang, S., Zhao, Y., & Zhao, Y. (In press). Bayesian mixed model inference for genetic association under related samples with brain network phenotype. Biostatistics, in press.

Wang, S., Wang, Y., Xu, F. H., Shen, L., & Zhao, Y. (n.d.). Establishing group-level brain structural connectivity incorporating anatomical knowledge under latent space modeling.

docs.title: Social Networks

Wang, S., Paul, S., & De Boeck, P. (2023). Joint latent space model for social networks with multivariate attributes. Psychometrika, 1–31.

docs.title: Bipartite Networks, Multivariate and Psychometric Analysis
docs.text:
Wang, S, & Edgerton, J. (2022). Resilience to stress in bipartite networks: application to the islamic state recruitment network. Journal of Complex Networks, 10(4), cnac017.

Wang, S., De Boeck, P., & Yotebieng, M. (2023). Heywood cases in unidimensional factor models and item response models for binary data. Applied Psychological Measurement, 47 (2), 141–154.

Wang, S, & De Boeck, P. (2022). Understanding the role of subpopulations and reliability in between-group studies. Behavior Research Methods, 1–16.

docs.title: Topics I am currently working on
Network-based neuroimaging methodology development
docs.text: Trajectory research, normative modeling, interplay between function and structure, brain-age research, imaging harmonization and imaging genetics

docs.title: Social and political network methology development and applications
docs.text: Terrorist networks, mobility networks, education networks and educational outcomes

docs.title: Data science and machine learning topics
docs.text: Hypergraph, prediction versus inference and psychological applications

docs.title: jlsm
docs.text: An R package estimating joint latent space models for social networks and multivariate attributes using a fast inference approach.

docs.title: ABCModel
docs.text: An R package estimating the attributes-informed brain connectivity model.

docs.title: LatentSNA
docs.text:
An R package estimating the latent variables-assisted statistical network analysis model.
